stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the final level's 'retro section', a large-scale stage that combines elements from all 15 Super Mario 64 courses. The stream focuses on level layout, asset implementation, and managing the N64's memory constraints, while also discussing his game design philosophy and contingency plans for a potential Nintendo takedown.

development_findings.summary: The game's final level will feature a 'retro section' that is a large, vertical mashup of all 15 courses from the original Super Mario 64, inspired by the 'Only Up 64' romhack.
development_findings.quote: The retro section is not just level lava then, it's going to be every Mario 64 level at the same time. We're going to be retroing out so much.

development_findings.summary: The project is constrained by N64 memory limitations, forcing Kaze to be selective about level detail and monitor RAM usage closely, especially in the ambitious final level.
development_findings.quote: Our main issue here is that we are running out of memory. So we have to keep this somewhat low detail.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for the game encourages creative, intentional sequence breaking and skips, but he wants to avoid shortcuts that completely trivialize challenges.
development_findings.quote: I want there to be plenty of skips in this too, I think that's going to be essential to making this fun... I want player to at least be creative when they skip something, otherwise it's not fun.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle is that the game should be completable using only the standard Mario 64 moveset, with the new abilities providing alternative, easier, or faster routes.
development_findings.quote: I kind of want this game to be beatable without Mario's extended moveset.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively 'fixing' technical aspects of the original Mario 64 models he dislikes, such as UV mapping, while trying to maintain the overall classic aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I cannot tolerate what the original developers did here unfortunately. Okay I will die if I look at this for too long it is hazardous to look at this.

development_findings.summary: The next major development task after completing the final level is to build the Overworld, which will be a representation of Yoshi's Island split into multiple sections.
Kaze notes that he no longer uses old tools like Mario 64 Predator, recommending modern alternatives like 'bomb engine' for romhacking.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of a potential Nintendo takedown but views it as a win-win scenario, as it would provide a PR opportunity to rebrand the game with original assets and sell it commercially.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.

context_findings.summary: Kaze confirms he has a long history with Nintendo's content enforcement, with over 70 of his videos having been taken down, though none in the last 4-5 years.
context_findings.quote: You do realise Nintendo took down over 70 of my videos, like I'm very clearly on Nintendo's radar.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his creative process during streams as very in-the-moment and spontaneous, admitting he often forgets the ideas he discusses shortly after saying them.
context_findings.quote: Please keep note that when I'm streaming I am yapping, and when I'm yapping I do not remember anything I say. After two seconds, it's just out of my brain.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he has a daughter who is getting baptized and that his parents are visiting for 10 days, indicating that he balances his development work with significant family commitments.
Kaze works on paid commissions alongside his passion projects, as shown by a separate "drug mario" GTA-style game he briefly demonstrated.
Kaze expresses his philosophy on game design, critiquing franchises like Sonic for core design flaws and believing that significant experimentation is required to make a concept work.
context_findings.quote: I think the games just need a lot of experimentation before they ever showed up being good.

biobak.summary: Biobak created most of the levels for a separate, paid commission project Kaze is working on, described as a GTA-style 'drug mario' game.

zeina.summary: Zeina makes a brief appearance on stream. Kaze mentions they are watching an anime together, giving a small glimpse into their personal life as a couple.

key_stories.title: The Nintendo Takedown Strategy
key_stories.summary: Kaze confronts the risk of a Nintendo takedown not with fear, but with a strategic plan. He views a potential cease and desist as a PR opportunity to pivot the project into a commercial, original game he could sell on Steam, making the situation a 'win-win' for him.
key_stories.challenge: The constant threat of a copyright takedown from Nintendo for using their IP.
key_stories.process: Instead of working in fear, Kaze has developed a contingency plan. He would strip the project of all Nintendo assets and code, rebrand it as an original title like 'Return to Dinosaur Island', and leverage his 'banger ideas' for an original game.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has adopted a 'win-win' philosophy. He is prepared for a takedown and sees it as a strategic opportunity to pivot into a commercial indie game, using the publicity to his advantage.
key_stories.key_quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.

key_stories.title: Building the Retro-Flex Finale
key_stories.summary: Kaze is designing the game's final level to be a 'cool flex'â€”a single, massive stage combining elements from all 15 original Mario 64 courses. The process is a constant balancing act between his ambitious creative vision and the N64's strict technical memory constraints.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a final level that is a fitting climax for the game while working within the N64's severe memory limitations.
key_stories.process: Inspired by 'Only Up 64', Kaze began importing and stitching together geometry from every SM64 level. He's constantly checking memory usage, discussing level flow with chat, and problem-solving how to connect disparate areas into a fun, cohesive challenge.
key_stories.outcome: The level is still being built, but the concept is a vertical climb through sections of all 15 SM64 courses. Kaze is actively managing memory by keeping detail low and carefully selecting which assets to import.
key_stories.key_quote: And it's also going to be such a cool flex to see all of the levels at the same time.

key_stories.title: The Community Feedback-Driven Censorship
key_stories.summary: After receiving community feedback that a level in a separate project was perceived as offensive, Kaze immediately took the criticism on board. He decided to censor the level by changing its assets to ensure it was no longer offensive, demonstrating his responsiveness to his audience.
key_stories.challenge: A level in a commissioned project contained imagery that community members found offensive towards the LGBT community.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledged the community's feedback on stream. He stated that the offense was unintentional but recognized that the perception of it being offensive was what mattered. He then brainstormed a solution live to change the level's theme.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to remove the imagery and replace it with in-universe assets (Bowser flags), reframing the level's theme to be an 'anti-Bowser protest' to eliminate the offensive interpretation.
key_stories.key_quote: if we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad obviously

open_questions.context: Kaze has a detailed contingency plan to rebrand the game as 'Return to Dinosaur Island' and sell it on Steam if Nintendo takes down the hack. He claims he can just 'rip out their code and their assets'.
questions: How feasible is it to truly separate your custom code from the decompilation base? What would that process actually look like?
You mentioned you have 'banger ideas' for an original version. Can you share what some of those ideas are that you couldn't do with the Mario IP?
Would you feel more or less creative pressure if you were forced to create a fully original IP instead of a romhack?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned the next major step is building the Overworld, which will be 'all of Yoshi's Island' but split into 'multiple sections'.
questions: What is your core design philosophy for the overworld? How will players navigate between levels?
How will you make the overworld feel like one continuous island despite being technically split into multiple areas?
What are the biggest challenges you anticipate in building the overworld compared to building a self-contained course?

open_questions.context: Little was said about the collaborative process with key team members. Biobak was mentioned for a different project, and Badub was not mentioned at all.
questions: Can you walk us through the collaborative workflow? For example, how does a piece of music from Badub or an animation from Zeina go from an idea to being implemented in the game?
How do you provide creative feedback to your team on their contributions?
How are major creative decisions for the project made between the core team members?

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly mentions fixing 'bad' UV maps and geometry from the original SM64, but also wanting to preserve the 'vanilla shitty aesthetic'.
questions: Where do you personally draw the line between a technical flaw that needs fixing and an artistic quirk that's part of the N64 charm?
Can you give an example of an original SM64 'flaw' you intentionally chose to keep in the game?
What emotional response or feeling are you trying to evoke in players by curating this 'fixed but faithful' aesthetic?

open_questions.context: Kaze is working on paid commissions, like the 'drug mario' game, alongside a massive passion project. He also has significant family duties.
questions: How do you manage your time and creative energy between passion projects, paid work, and family life?
